column1: Menlo Park is a city located at the eastern edge of San Mateo County within the San Francisco Bay Area of California in the United States. It is bordered by San Francisco Bay on the north and east; East Palo Alto
column3: and Stanford to the south; and Atherton
column5: and Redwood City to the west. Menlo Park is one of the most educated cities in  California and the United States;  nearly 70% of residents over the age of 25 have earned a bachelor's degree or higher. Menlo Park had 32
column6: 026 inhabitants according to the 2010 United States Census
column7: which had grown to an estimated 34
column8: 698 inhabitants by 2019. The city is home to the corporate headquarters of  Facebook
column9: and is where Google and Round Table Pizza were founded.

column1: According to the United States Census Bureau
column2: the city has a total area of 17.4 square miles (45 km2)
column3: of which 9.8 square miles (25 km2) are land and 7.6 square miles (20 km2) are covered by water.  Menlo Park is long and narrow on a northeast to southwest axis. The northeast portion borders the San Francisco Bay and includes the Dumbarton Bridge that connects Menlo Park to Fremont on the east side of the bay. The city shoreline includes the city's largest park
column4: Bedwell Bayfront Park (160 acres (65 ha)) and the Don Edwards San Francisco Bay National Wildlife Refuge. San Francisquito Creek marks much of the southeast border of the city. West Menlo Park (not part of the city despite its name) along Alameda de las Pulgas nearly separates the southwestern part of the city (known as Sharon Heights) from the rest. The extreme southwest is clipped by Interstate 280.

column1: The Bayshore Freeway (part of U.S. Route 101)  traverses Menlo Park northwest to southeast near the shoreline and somewhat parallel to it to the southwest is El Camino Real. The intersection of El Camino Real and  Santa Cruz Avenue is considered the heart of the city. Nearby
column2: the Menlo Park Civic Center is bounded by Ravenswood Avenue
column3: Alma Street
column5: and Burgess Drive. It contains the council offices
column9: which has various recreational facilities. Other major roads include Sand Hill Road in the Sharon Heights area.

column1: The residential areas of Menlo Park can be unofficially divided into several neighborhoods. From "east" (northeast toward San Francisco Bay) to "west" (southwest toward the Pacific Coast)
column2: they are defined by the Palo Alto Weekly as: Belle Haven is the only neighborhood east of Route 101; much of the rest of that area is business or protected land.  Between 101 and the roughly parallel Middlefield Road are the neighborhoods of the Willows
column3: Suburban Park
column7: and South of Seminary (the seminary being Saint Patrick's Seminary). Between Middlefield and El Camino Real are the Caltrain track and Felton Gables
column9: and Park Forest. West of El Camino until the foothills of the Peninsula are the neighborhoods of Downtown Menlo Park
column11: and Allied Arts (sometimes also known as Stanford Park
column12: it is named for the Allied Arts Guild in it). In the hills are Sharon Heights and Stanford Hills. Several other neighborhoods are closely associated with Menlo Park but are actually in unincorporated San Mateo county; these include Menlo Oaks and Fair Oaks (latter part of the North Fair Oaks census area) between Bayshore and Middlefield
column13: University Heights (also known as West Menlo Park) between Sharon Heights and most of the rest of the city
column15: which is somewhat near Stanford Hills.

column1: The area of Menlo Park was inhabited by the Ohlone people when the Portolá expedition arrived in 1769.In 1795
column2: the Rancho de las Pulgas land grant was made that included the area of the current city.

column3: Dennis J. Oliver and his brother-in-law D. C. McGlynn
column5: 700-acre (690 ha) tract of land on the former Rancho de las Pulgas. In 1854
column6: they erected a gate with a wooden arch bearing the inscription "Menlo Park" and the date "August 1854" at the entrance to their property (now the intersection of Middle Ave and El Camino Real). The word "Menlo" derived from the owners' former home of Menlough in County Galway
column8: and is an Anglicized version of the original Irish name of the place
column11: the San Francisco and San Jose Rail Road had built the railroad from San Francisco to as far as Mayfield (now California Avenue station in Palo Alto) and started running trains to the area. They named a nearby station "Menlo Park" after the sign. The 1867 station building still stands on the platform of the current Caltrain station
column12: used by the local Chamber of Commerce. It holds the record as the oldest
column13: continually operating train station in California. The town of Menlo Park grew up around this station
column14: becoming a popular home for San Francisco businessmen. A post office was established in 1870
column15: and the city was incorporated in 1874 (it dissolved after two years
column16: but later was permanently incorporated in 1927). The original arch
column17: which gave its name to the stations and ultimately
column20: when the original arch was destroyed in an automobile accident. The origin of the name of Menlo Park
column21: California (circa 1850) antedates any work done by Thomas Edison (circa 1876) in Menlo Park
column26: a large portion of Menlo Park was the site of Camp Fremont
column30: 000 men being sent to fight in World War I. It did not last long (the camp was dismantled after the war)
column31: but army engineers paved the first streets in Menlo Park and laid the first water and gas lines. The army did retain the camp hospital
column32: and it is now the site of a Veterans Administration hospital off of Willow Road in Menlo Park. In the autumn of 1918
column33: a flu pandemic hit Camp Fremont and killed 147.At the start of World War II
column34: the US government bought the 260-acre (110 ha) estate of Timothy Hopkins from his widow and created the Palo Alto General Hospital
column35: later renamed the Dibble General Hospital (after Colonel John Dibble
column36: who was killed in 1943). After the war ended
column37: some of the land was sold to the city and became the sites of the main library and city hall. More of the land was bought by Stanford University to house the increase in students due to the G.I. Bill; the area was known as the "Stanford Village"
column38: which existed as student housing until the mid-1960s. This land also was the site of the Stanford Research Institute (now SRI International) starting in 1947; between 1955 and 1968
column39: SRI bought the rest of the Stanford Village.In the 1960s
column40: the former 600-acre (240 ha) estate of Frederick W. Sharon (1859–1914) (son of Senator William Sharon) and his wife
column41: Louise Tevis Breckinridge Sharon (1858–1938;  daughter of Lloyd Tevis and divorced wife of John Witherspoon Breckinridge)
column42: in the hills of south west Menlo Park was developed and called "Sharon Heights".

column2: the central portions of Menlo Park are served by the Menlo Park City School District
column3: while the Belle Haven neighborhood and VA hospital are served by the Ravenswood City School District
column4: and the Sharon Heights and Stanford Hills neighborhoods served by the Las Lomitas Elementary School District. For high school
column5: Menlo Park is part of the Sequoia Union High School District
column6: with all of Menlo Park falling into the boundaries of Menlo-Atherton High School or TIDE Academy
column7: a small high school established in 2019. Catholic parochial schools are St. Raymond Catholic Elementary School and Nativity Elementary School. Peninsula School is a private progressive primary school. Trinity School is an Episcopalian elementary school.

column1: Private schools include Phillips Brooks School
column2: a pre-K to 5th grade institution with about 290 students and Alto International School
column3: formerly known as German-American International School
column6: is also in the city.For higher education
column7: Saint Patrick's Seminary and University is a Catholic seminary in Menlo Park. Fuller Theological Seminary
column9: has a branch campus in Menlo Park.There are two libraries within the city
column10: the Main branch and the Belle Haven branch. These libraries are part of the Peninsula Library System and share many resources with other nearby libraries.
